quote: 'Tis certain so. The Prince woos for himself. Friendship is constant in all other things save in the office and affairs of love.
Go to, then. Your considerate stone. D not much dislike the matter, but the manner of his speech; for 't cannot be we shall remain in friendship, our conditions so diff'ring in their acts.
Think so, too. But you shall find the band that seems to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of their amity.
Heigh-ho, sing heigh-ho, unto the green holly. Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly.
Heigh-ho, sing heigh-ho, unto the green holly. Most friendship is feigning, most loving mere folly.
Prithee, put up. Noble shalt thou have, and present pay, and liquor likewise will give to thee, and friendship shall combine, and brotherhood.

Chair, goes about the court, comes to the King, sir, desire you do me right and justice, and to bestow your pity on me; for am a most poor woman and a stranger, born out of your dominions, having here no judge indifferent nor no more assurance of equal friendship and proceeding.
But, in the beaten way of friendship, what make you at elsinore?
If then the King your father will restore but that one half which is unsatisfied, we will give up our right in Aquitaine, and hold fair friendship with his Majesty.

All schooldays' friendship, childhood innocence? We, Hermia, like two artificial gods, have with our needles created both one flower, both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion, both warbling of one song, both in one key, as if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds had been incorporate.

Now tell me, Proteus, what's your will with me? M gracious lord, that which would discover the law of friendship bids me to conceal, but when call to mind your gracious favors done to me, undeserving as am, my duty pricks me on to utter that which else no worldly good should draw from me.
play: (The Two Gentlemen of Verona, Act 20, Scene 1)

quote: Sure there cannot. D not think it possible our friendship should ever leave us.
Friendship, blood, and all the ties between us disclaim if thou once think upon her.
Desire you in friendship, and will one way or other make you amends.
play: (The Merry Wives of Windsor, Act 23, Scene 34)
